content.webTitle: Where can I buy an eco school uniform?

fields.headline: Where can I buy an eco school uniform?
fields.bodyText: While the nation's kids mope into their cornflakes, the apparel trade gets disrespectfully excited about the start of the new school year, with feverish speculation over teen clothing, school uniform and sportswear sales. Hardly surprising: the UK uniform market is worth £1bn. Parents often feel they are stuck somewhere between buying kit from a monopolistic enterprise charging top dollar for logo-ed sweatshirts, or driven into the arms of supermarkets who can kit out a child in synthetics and cotton made in unknown conditions for under £10. Peopleandplanet.org runs the Wear Fair campaign, which wants schools in fair-trade uniforms by 2015. There's also a big opportunity to turn the "school run" into something positive. Over the past two decades the number of children being driven to school (many as sole passenger) has doubled – a fifth of all traffic on roads during peak hours can be attributed to the school run. Carbon emissions aside, pint-sized volunteers wearing accelerometers have pinpointed the "active" school commute as an overlooked fat buster and cardio booster. Kids who walked or cycled to school didn't just expend significantly more kilo calories during the commute but were more active than car travellers after school, too. For a guide on creating a human bus try walkingschoolbus.org or bightkidz.co.uk. Form an orderly crocodile please. If you only do one thing this week Coinciding with the annual September spike in birth rates is the NCT Nearly New Sale which diverts 300 tonnes of baby clothes and equipment into appreciative homes rather than into landfill. nct.org.uk/nearlynewsales If you have any ethical questions, email lucy.siegle@observer.co.uk
